activities.name: Local Water Quality Research Project
activities.description: Conducted independent research on microplastic contamination in local waterways, presented findings to city council
activities.impact: Research influenced new water treatment protocols, findings published in state environmental journal

activities.name: Environmental Justice Club
activities.description: Founded club focused on environmental issues affecting underrepresented communities
activities.impact: Organized 5 community cleanups, raised $3,000 for environmental organizations, increased environmental awareness in low-income neighborhoods

activities.name: Youth Climate Action Network
activities.description: Coordinated climate action events across 10 high schools, lobbied state representatives on environmental policy
activities.impact: Engaged 500+ students in climate activism, contributed to passage of state renewable energy bill

core_values.description: Believe environmental protection must address impacts on all communities, especially the most vulnerable
Committed to evidence-based solutions and methodical research approaches
Believe young people have both the responsibility and power to address environmental challenges

defining_moments.title: Discovering Microplastics in My Childhood Creek
defining_moments.description: The creek where I played as a child always seemed pristine, but when I tested it for my research project, I found alarming levels of microplastic contamination. This discovery transformed my understanding of how environmental damage can be invisible yet pervasive, and motivated my commitment to environmental research and advocacy.
defining_moments.emotional_impact: Shocked and saddened by the contamination, then determined to understand and address it
defining_moments.lessons_learned: Environmental problems often hide in plain sight, requiring scientific investigation to uncover and address

defining_moments.title: Presenting Research to Skeptical City Council Members
defining_moments.description: When I presented my water quality findings to the city council, several members questioned both my methodology and my age. I had to defend my research rigorously while maintaining composure. Eventually, my data convinced them to implement new monitoring protocols, teaching me the power of well-conducted science to drive policy change.
defining_moments.emotional_impact: Nervous and frustrated by skepticism, then validated when research was accepted
defining_moments.lessons_learned: Strong data and clear communication can overcome age-based bias and create real change

defining_moments.title: Organizing Environmental Justice in Low-Income Neighborhoods
defining_moments.description: Working with the environmental justice club, I learned that pollution disproportionately affects communities of color and low-income areas. Organizing cleanups in these neighborhoods taught me that environmental science must address social inequity, not just technical problems.
defining_moments.emotional_impact: Angry about environmental inequality, then motivated to work toward justice
defining_moments.lessons_learned: Environmental science without social justice is incomplete—we must address both technical and equity challenges

model_extra.essay_prompt: How do you hope to use your Harvard education in the future?
